Used stuff like this to clean Schott filters and NMR tubes. If prepared right on the surface to be cleaned, seems even more effective. Also works with 5% H2O2, still more effective for filters than 100% HNO3))

I am having a strange problem with my piranha solution that I am using to dissolve nickel and zinc metal. In my reaction I am getting a solid precipitating out after most of the H2O2 is used up. The nickel precipitate is a lighter green than the nickel sulfate solution, and the zinc precipitate is a pure white. My only though is since I am using drain cleaner as my source of sulfuric acid that there is something in it causing some zinc and nickel compounds to crash out of solution.

I find that the HCl + H2O2 mixture is also very effective at cleaning off organic stains. It is prepared in the same way, take special care to add the peroxide TO the acid.

I'm not entirely certain how it works, I have a feeling it promotes the generation of some free Chlorine radicals and molecules that rip apart organic molecules. The mixture becomes greenish yellow and "fizzy", emitting bubbles if disturbed. The mixture is surprisingly stable for a good while in air and can be transferred from one stained piece of glassware to another for cleaning them. It won't produce any fireworks, which is OK in my book, and yet still gets the job done on those pesky persistent stains. I use it regularly for cleaning glass filters.
